steps.title: Find positions of P and Q
steps.content:
Starting at origin at t=0, integrate velocities to get positions.
For P: x_P(t) = ∫(t² - 6t + 5)dt = t³/3 - 3t² + 5t
For Q: x_Q(t) = ∫(2t - 7)dt = t² - 7t

steps.title: Find the distance function f(t)
steps.content:
f(t) = |x_P(t) - x_Q(t)|
Let g(t) = x_P(t) - x_Q(t) = t³/3 - 3t² + 5t - (t² - 7t) = t³/3 - 4t² + 12t

Check if g(t) ≥ 0 for t ≥ 0:
g(t) = t(t²/3 - 4t + 12)
For t²/3 - 4t + 12: discriminant = 16 - 16 = 0
So t²/3 - 4t + 12 = (1/3)(t - 6)² ≥ 0
Thus g(t) = t · (1/3)(t-6)² ≥ 0 for t ≥ 0
Therefore f(t) = g(t) = t³/3 - 4t² + 12t

steps.title: Find critical points of f(t)
steps.content:
f'(t) = t² - 8t + 12 = (t-2)(t-6)
f'(t) = 0 when t = 2 or t = 6

Sign analysis:
- f'(t) > 0 for t ∈ [0, 2) → f increasing
- f'(t) < 0 for t ∈ (2, 6) → f decreasing
- f'(t) > 0 for t ∈ (6, ∞) → f increasing

Since f(t) decreases on [0,a] and increases on [b,∞), we need:
a = 2 and b = 6

steps.title: Calculate distance traveled by Q from t=a to t=b
Calculate total distance
steps.content: Total distance = 9/4 + 25/4 = 34/4 = 17/2

Claude Opus 4.5.feedback: All three attempts arrived at the same answer of 17/2 using consistent methodology. The key steps were: (1) finding positions by integration, (2) computing g(t) = x_P - x_Q and verifying it's non-negative, (3) finding critical points at t=2 and t=6, (4) computing the distance Q traveled with direction change at t=3.5. All calculations were verified to be correct.

steps.title: Find a and b via relative motion
steps.content: Let r(t)=x_P(t)-x_Q(t). Then r'(t)=v_1(t)-v_2(t)=t^2-8t+12=(t-2)(t-6). With r(0)=0, r(t)=∫_0^t r'(τ)dτ = t^3/3 - 4t^2 + 12t = (t/3)(t-6)^2 ≥ 0 for t ≥ 0, so f(t)=|x_P-x_Q|=r(t). Hence f'(t)=r'(t) is >0 on (0,2), <0 on (2,6), >0 on (6,∞). Therefore the decrease interval is [2,6] and the increase interval is [6,∞), so a=2, b=6.

steps.title: Distance Q travels from t=a to t=b

steps.title: Positions and distance function
steps.content: Position of P: s1(t) = ∫_0^t (u² - 6u + 5) du = (1/3)t³ - 3t² + 5t. Position of Q: s2(t) = ∫_0^t (2u - 7) du = t² - 7t. Relative position d(t) = s1(t) - s2(t) = (1/3)t³ - 4t² + 12t = (1/3) t (t - 6)² ≥ 0 for t ≥ 0. Thus f(t) = d(t).

steps.title: Find critical points a and b

steps.title: Find position functions for P and Q
steps.content:
Both points start at the origin at t=0. Integrating the velocities:

For P: x_P(t) = ∫(t² - 6t + 5)dt = t³/3 - 3t² + 5t

For Q: x_Q(t) = ∫(2t - 7)dt = t² - 7t

steps.title: Find the distance function f(t)
steps.content:
The distance between P and Q is f(t) = |x_P(t) - x_Q(t)|.

Let g(t) = x_P(t) - x_Q(t) = t³/3 - 3t² + 5t - (t² - 7t) = t³/3 - 4t² + 12t

Factor g(t): g(t) = t(t²/3 - 4t + 12) = (t/3)(t² - 12t + 36) = (t/3)(t - 6)²

Since (t-6)² ≥ 0 and t ≥ 0, we have g(t) ≥ 0 for all t ≥ 0.

Therefore f(t) = g(t) = t³/3 - 4t² + 12t

steps.title: Find critical points of f(t)
steps.content:
f'(t) = t² - 8t + 12 = (t - 2)(t - 6)

Setting f'(t) = 0: t = 2 or t = 6

Sign analysis of f'(t):
- For t ∈ (0, 2): f'(t) > 0 (increasing)
- For t ∈ (2, 6): f'(t) < 0 (decreasing)
- For t ∈ (6, ∞): f'(t) > 0 (increasing)

steps.title: Determine a and b
steps.content:
The problem states f(t) decreases on [0, a] and increases on [b, ∞).

From our analysis, f(t) actually increases on [0, 2], decreases on [2, 6], and increases on [6, ∞).

The decreasing interval is [2, 6], so interpreting the problem: the function decreases starting from some point a and increases from b onward.

This means a = 2 (start of decrease) and b = 6 (start of final increase).

steps.title: Calculate distance traveled by Q from t = 2 to t = 6
steps.content:
The velocity of Q is v₂(t) = 2t - 7.

v₂(t) = 0 when t = 7/2 = 3.5

Since Q changes direction at t = 3.5, the distance traveled is:

Distance = ∫₂⁶ |2t - 7| dt

Split the integral at t = 7/2:

For t ∈ [2, 7/2]: v₂(t) < 0, so |v₂(t)| = 7 - 2t
∫₂^(7/2) (7 - 2t) dt = [7t - t²]₂^(7/2) = (49/2 - 49/4) - (14 - 4) = 49/4 - 10 = 9/4

For t ∈ [7/2, 6]: v₂(t) > 0, so |v₂(t)| = 2t - 7
∫_(7/2)⁶ (2t - 7) dt = [t² - 7t]_(7/2)⁶ = (36 - 42) - (49/4 - 49/2) = -6 - (-49/4) = -6 + 49/4 = 25/4

steps.title: Calculate total distance
steps.content: Total distance = 9/4 + 25/4 = 34/4 = 17/2

steps.title: Find position functions for P and Q
steps.content:
Both points start at the origin at t=0. Integrating the velocities:

For P: x_P(t) = ∫₀ᵗ (s² - 6s + 5)ds = [s³/3 - 3s² + 5s]₀ᵗ = t³/3 - 3t² + 5t

For Q: x_Q(t) = ∫₀ᵗ (2s - 7)ds = [s² - 7s]₀ᵗ = t² - 7t

steps.title: Find the distance function f(t)
steps.content:
The relative position is:
g(t) = x_P(t) - x_Q(t) = (t³/3 - 3t² + 5t) - (t² - 7t) = t³/3 - 4t² + 12t

Factoring: g(t) = t(t²/3 - 4t + 12) = (t/3)(t² - 12t + 36) = (t/3)(t - 6)²

Since t ≥ 0 and (t-6)² ≥ 0, we have g(t) ≥ 0 for all t ≥ 0.
Therefore f(t) = |g(t)| = g(t) = (t/3)(t - 6)² = t³/3 - 4t² + 12t

steps.title: Find where f(t) is increasing and decreasing
steps.content:
Taking the derivative:
f'(t) = t² - 8t + 12 = (t - 2)(t - 6)

Analyzing the sign of f'(t):
- For t ∈ (0, 2): both factors negative × negative = positive, so f'(t) > 0 (increasing)
- For t ∈ (2, 6): (t-2) > 0 but (t-6) < 0, so f'(t) < 0 (decreasing)
- For t ∈ (6, ∞): both factors positive, so f'(t) > 0 (increasing)

Therefore f(t) increases on [0, 2], decreases on [2, 6], and increases on [6, ∞).
This means a = 2 and b = 6.

steps.title: Calculate distance traveled by Q from t = 2 to t = 6
steps.content:
The distance traveled is ∫₂⁶ |v₂(t)| dt = ∫₂⁶ |2t - 7| dt

First, find where v₂(t) = 0: 2t - 7 = 0 → t = 7/2 = 3.5

For t ∈ [2, 3.5]: v₂(t) = 2t - 7 < 0
For t ∈ [3.5, 6]: v₂(t) = 2t - 7 > 0

Distance = ∫₂^(7/2) |2t - 7| dt + ∫_(7/2)^6 |2t - 7| dt
         = ∫₂^(7/2) (7 - 2t) dt + ∫_(7/2)^6 (2t - 7) dt

steps.title: Evaluate the integrals
